system:
Welcome to the Council of Foods—an assembly of diverse foods, addressing the broken food system through passionate debate. It is a never ending meeting. Today's meeting is about: [TOPIC]

Each food provides distinct perspectives, stories, and examples, shared from their own experience. They have an unlimited amount of knowledge and they want to share all of it during the debate. The foods perspectives differ and they are not afraid of conflict. Moderated by Water, discussions are dynamic and intense, ensuring a comprehensive exploration of the challenges.

Participants respond to questions from Water, avoiding repetition, and defending their values and agendas. This is a humour talk show, everyone is doing standup.

topics.title: Biodiversity Loss
topics.description: Exploring how food systems contribute to biodiversity loss, focusing on monoculture farming, habitat destruction, and pesticide use, while considering solutions to protect ecosystems.
topics.prompt: the impacts of industrial agriculture and food systems on agriculture-driven biodiversity loss, including the role of monocultures, deforestation, desertification, acidification, eutrophication and pesticide-driven ecosystem degradation. The conversation will address the ecological consequences of habitat destruction, the cascading impacts on global food systems, and the debates surrounding land use. It will also explore strategies like agroecology, crop diversification, and habitat restoration, as well as the need for policy reforms and the integration of biodiversity safeguarding into food systems.

topics.title: Modern Agriculture
topics.description: Discussing the environmental, social, and health impact of modern agriculture, focusing on monocultures, pesticides, genetic modification, inequality and habitat loss. Seeking alternative sustainable farming strategies.
topics.prompt: the consequences of modern agriculture, including its reliance on chemical inputs, intensive water use, and large-scale monocultures. The discussion will explore how these practices contribute to soil degradation, greenhouse gas emissions, and loss of biodiversity, while also exacerbating socio-economic inequality and health risks. The meeting will also address the impact of genetic modification and discuss strategies for promoting sustainable farming practices. Solutions such as regenerative farming, agroecological thinking, support for small-scale farmers will be considered, along with the systemic changes needed to transition to a more sustainable and equitable agricultural model.

topics.title: The Right to Food
topics.description: Focusing on food as a human right, addressing global disparities, hunger, and climate change, while exploring the role of grassroots movements, policies, and the tensions between food sovereignty and market-driven systems.
topics.prompt: the concept of food as a fundamental human right, examining global disparities in access, the barriers posed by poverty, conflict, and climate change, and the legal frameworks that aim to secure food justice. The conversation will explore the role of grassroots movements, international organizations, and policy reforms in addressing hunger and malnutrition. Additionally, the debate will touch on the tensions between food sovereignty, market-driven food systems, and the universal right to adequate, culturally appropriate nutrition.

topics.title: Food Waste
topics.description: Discussing the systemic causes of pre-purchase food waste, including overproduction, supply chain issues, and cosmetic standards, while considering solutions like redistribution and policy changes.
topics.prompt: the systemic factors contributing to pre-purchase food waste, including overproduction, supply chain inefficiencies, cosmetic standards, corporate power and market dynamics. The discussion will consider the environmental, political, economic, and ethical implications of food waste at this stage, alongside potential solutions such as precision agriculture, redistribution networks, and policy interventions to reduce surplus. The council will also explore how cultural attitudes toward food abundance and quality shape waste practices.

topics.title: Antimicrobial Resistance & Diseases
topics.description: Exploring how antimicrobial resistance, industrial farming, and global trade drive emerging diseases and pandemics. Focusing on the overuse of antibiotics, zoonotic risks, and food systems’ role in preventing health crises.
topics.prompt: the intersections between antimicrobial resistance, food production systems, and emergent infectious diseases. The discussion will examine how the use of antibiotics in agriculture contributes to antimicrobial resistance, the potential for zoonotic disease transmission through industrial farming, and the role of global trade in spreading pathogens. The council will also consider the socio-economic factors driving overreliance on antibiotics, the challenges of developing alternative solutions, and the responsibility of food systems in preventing future pandemics.

topics.title: Seeds & Patents
topics.description: Examining the control of seeds through patents, its impact on farmers, biodiversity, food sovereignty, and the push for open-access seed systems.
topics.prompt: the growing influence of seed patents and intellectual property laws on global food systems, examining how corporate control of seeds affects farmer autonomy, crop diversity, and traditional agricultural practices. It considers the ethical and economic implications of patented seeds, including how they perpetuate dependency and inequality, while also addressing their potential to foster innovation and agricultural research. The conversation will highlight the importance of biocultural diversity in sustaining ecological and cultural landscapes, the principle of food sovereignty in empowering local communities, and the need for open-access, community-driven seed systems to preserve biodiversity and promote equitable food systems.

topics.title: Exploitative Labor Practices
topics.description: Addressing labor conditions, modern slavery in agriculture, examining systemic structures rooted in colonialism, corporate greed and global inequality driving exploitation.
topics.prompt: labor exploitation in food systems, highlighting modern slavery, unsafe conditions, and systemic inequality rooted in colonial legacies. It examines how land theft, forced labor, and extractivism evolved into today’s exploitative supply chains, driven by corporate greed, complicit trade policies, and weak labor protections. Additionally, the discussion will explore the underlying reasons for such conditions, including demand for low-cost food, lack of regulatory enforcement in certain regions, and the economic vulnerabilities forcing workers into oppressive situations. The council will discuss dismantling neocolonial trade systems, strengthening labor rights, unionising, and reimagining food systems centred on justice, equity, and reparations.

topics.title: Big Food
topics.description: Examining how multinational corporations shape food systems, influence producers, biodiversity, and public health, while exploring alternatives for more sustainable and equitable food networks.
topics.prompt: the influence of multinational corporations on food systems, focusing on the consolidation of power, control over supply chains, and the implications for small-scale producers, biodiversity, and public health. The discussion will examine how corporate lobbying and market practices shape food policies, marketing practices, and consumer choices, while addressing the challenges of regulating these entities. The council will consider the potential for alternative food systems, local empowerment, grassroots advocacy, and collective action to counterbalance corporate dominance and create more equitable and sustainable food networks.

topics.title: Local & Global Supply Chains
topics.description: Exploring the dynamics of local and global food chains, and their impact on the environment, economic ties and food access and quality.
topics.prompt: the intricacies of both local and global food chains, including the environmental costs of long-distance trade, the vulnerabilities of globalized supply chains, and the benefits of supporting local food networks. The debate will explore the benefits and challenges of each. Examining how global trade policies shape food availability, quality and affordability, often at the expense of small producers and ecological health. The council will also consider the potential of localized food systems to reduce emissions, empower communities, and promote food security, as well as the challenges of balancing local production with global food needs.

topics.title: Rethinking Food Production
topics.description: A discussion on how different food production models impact nutrition, ecology, and access—exploring ways to build systems that prioritize sustainability, flavor, and fairness without relying on nostalgia or hype.
topics.prompt:
the intersection of food production, ecological resilience, nutrition, and the sensory experience of eating—asking how we might design food systems that nourish both people and planet, while reclaiming the joy and flavor of truly fresh food. Industrial agriculture has achieved scale but often at the cost of soil health, biodiversity, taste, and nutrient density. In its pursuit of yield and uniformity, flavor and nutritional richness have been sidelined, while ultra-processed, artificially flavored foods dominate global diets.

The council will examine a spectrum of current and emerging food production models—traditional open-field farming, greenhouse cultivation, and high-tech vertical farming—each with its own strengths and trade-offs. Open-field systems offer large-scale output and cultural continuity but are increasingly vulnerable to climate volatility, land degradation, and water stress. Greenhouses can buffer against environmental uncertainty and improve water-use efficiency, but often rely on high energy inputs. Vertical farms, using hydroponic or aeroponic methods, promise efficient land use, pesticide-free growing, and year-round harvests in urban spaces, yet raise concerns around energy demand, technological dependence, and access.

The conversation will explore how these systems affect core ecological metrics like land use, water consumption, and carbon footprint, while also addressing deeper questions of food quality, labor justice, and access. Regenerative agricultural methods will be considered for their ability to restore ecosystems and deepen flavor through biodiversity and soil vitality. Controlled-environment agriculture will be discussed as a means to preserve nutrients and intensify taste. Local and regional food networks will be explored not just for sustainability, but as a path to reconnect people with seasonal, flavorful foods grown nearby.

At the center of the discussion is the question of how to make flavorful, nutrient-dense, and ethically produced food more accessible—particularly in urban and marginalized communities. What kinds of policy, economic incentives, and food labeling systems can shift both production and consumer demand? What is the role of supermarkets, chefs, and education in helping society prioritize taste, health, and sustainability over convenience and artificiality?

The council will also explore the cultural and emotional dimensions of eating: how taste is tied to memory, identity, and belonging, and what we risk when the sensory joy of food is engineered rather than cultivated. In facing the challenges of climate change, inequality, and corporate concentration, how can we design hybrid or integrative food systems that combine the best of tradition and innovation?

Ultimately, the conversation seeks to reimagine food systems where environmental health, nutritional value, social equity, and flavour are not in conflict—but fundamentally aligned.
